sen.j: 柳 宗悦（やなぎ むねよし、1889年3月21日 - 1961年5月3日）は、民芸運動を起こした思想家、宗教哲学者、美術研究家。
sen.e: Muneyoshi YANAGI (March 21, 1889-May 3, 1961) was the thinker, religious philospher, and art scholar who triggered Mingei (National Art) Movement.
Muneyoshi YANAGI (March 21, 1889-May 3, 1961) was a thinker, religious philospher, and art scholar who triggered the Mingei (National Art) Movement.
Muneyoshi YANAGI (March 21, 1889 - May 3, 1961) was a thinker, religious philosopher, and art scholar who triggered the Mingei (National Art) Movement.
sen.cmt: philosopherスペル訂正しました。スペース補足しました。

sen.j: 来歴・人物
sen.e: Biography and Personal Profile
Biography and Personal Profile
Biography and Personal Profile

sen.j: 東京府（現：東京都）生まれ。
sen.e: He was born in Tokyofu (current Tokyoto (Tokyo Prefecture)).
He was born in Tokyofu (current Tokyoto (Tokyo Prefecture)).
He was born in Tokyo Prefecture (current Tokyo Metropolitan).
sen.cmt: 地名の表記を訂正しました。

sen.j: 海軍少将柳楢悦の三男。
sen.e: He was the third son of Narayoshi YANAGI, who had the title of Marine Major General.
He was the third son of Narayoshi YANAGI, who had the title of Marine Major General.
He was the third son of Narayoshi YANAGI, who had the title of Marine Major General.

sen.j: 学習院を経て東京大学卒業。
sen.e: He studied at Gakushuin School and graduated from Tokyo University.
He studied at Gakushuin School and graduated from Tokyo University.
He studied at Gakushuin School and graduated from Tokyo University.

sen.j: 専攻は宗教哲学であった。
sen.e: His major was the Philosophy of Religion.
His major was the Philosophy of Religion.
His major was the Philosophy of Religion.

sen.j: 嘉納治五郎の甥に当たり、嘉納に招かれるようにしてに千葉・我孫子（現：我孫子市）住んだ。
sen.e: He was the nephew of Jigoro KANO and started to live in Abiko after being invited by Kano.
sen.cmt: 原文では、「加納」となっていましたが、「嘉納」だと判断しましたので修正しました。
sen.e: He was the nephew of Jigoro KANO and started to live in Abiko after being invited by Kano.
He was the nephew of Jigoro KANO and started to live in Abiko, Chiba Prefecture (current Abiko City) after being invited by Kano.
sen.cmt: 原文に抜けがあるので訂正しました。

sen.j: さらに志賀直哉らを呼び、我孫子に文人らが集結するきっかけをつくった。
sen.e: He then invited Naoya SHIGA and found the opportunity to gather men of literature in Abiko.
He then invited Naoya SHIGA and found the opportunity to gather men of literature in Abiko.
He then invited Naoya SHIGA and found the opportunity to gather men of literature in Abiko.

sen.j: 学習院在学中、同人雑誌グループ白樺派に参加。
sen.e: He participated in a group of Doujin Magazine (a self-publishing magazine created by a group of similar interest), Shirakaba school, while studying at Gakushuin School.
He participated in a group of Doujin Magazine (a self-publishing magazine created by a group of similar interest), Shirakaba school, while studying at Gakushuin School.
He participated in a group of Doujin Magazine (a self-publishing magazine created by a group of similar interest), Shirakaba school, while studying at Gakushuin School.

sen.j: 生活に即した民芸品に注目して「用の美」を唱え、民芸運動を起こした。
sen.e: He declared the 'beauty of usage' by focusing on folk art that was used for living, and triggered Mingei Movement.
He declared the 'beauty of usage' by focusing on folk art that was used for living, and triggered the Mingei Movement.
He declared the 'beauty of usage' by focusing on folk art that was used for living, and triggered the Mingei Movement.

sen.j: 1936年、東京府東京市目黒区駒場 (目黒区)（現：東京都目黒区）に日本民藝館を設立。
sen.e: He established Nihon Mingeikan (the Japan Folk Crafts Museum) in Komaba, Meguro Ward, Tokyo City, Tokyo Prefecture (Current Meguro Ward, Tokyo Prefecture) in 1936.
He established Nihon Mingeikan (the Japan Folk Crafts Museum) in Komaba, Meguro Ward, Tokyo City, Tokyo Prefecture (Current Meguro Ward, Tokyo Prefecture) in 1936.
He established Nihon Mingeikan (the Japan Folk Crafts Museum) in Komaba, Meguro Ward, Tokyo City, Tokyo Prefecture (current Meguro Ward, Tokyo Prefecture) in 1936.
sen.cmt: current 小文字にしました。全角の括弧を半角にしました。

sen.j: 脳卒中で1961年5月3日逝去。
sen.e: He passed away on May 3, 1961 due to a brain stroke.
He passed away on May 3, 1961 due to a stroke.
He passed away on May 3, 1961 due to a stroke.

sen.j: 1914年柳兼子と結婚。
sen.e: He married Kaneko YANAGI in 1914.
He married Kaneko YANAGI in 1914.
He married Kaneko YANAGI in 1914.

sen.j: 柳兼子は近代日本を代表する女性声楽（アルト）。
sen.e: Kaneko YANAGI was the female singer (alto singer), who represented the modern day Japan.
Kaneko YANAGI was a female singer (alto singer), who represented modern day Japan.
Kaneko YANAGI was a female singer (alto singer), who represented modern day Japan.

sen.j: 工業デザイナーの柳宗理（長男）、美術史家の柳宗玄（次男）、園芸家の柳宗民（三男）は息子。
sen.e: His sons were Sori YANAGI (eldest son), who was the industrial designer, Munemoto YANAGI (second son), and Munetami YANAGI (third son), who was a horticulturist.
His sons were Sori YANAGI (eldest son), who was an industrial designer, Munemoto YANAGI (second son), and Munetami YANAGI (third son), who was a horticulturist.
His sons were Sori YANAGI (eldest son), who was an industrial designer, Munemoto YANAGI (second son), and Munetami YANAGI (third son), who was a horticulturist.

sen.j: 甥に染織家の柳悦孝、美術史家の石丸重治。
sen.e: His nephews were Yoshitaka YANAGI, who was from the dyeing and weaving Family, and Juji ISHIMARU who was the art historian.
His nephews were Yoshitaka YANAGI, who was from a dyeing and weaving Family, and Juji ISHIMARU who was an art historian.
His nephews were Yoshitaka YANAGI, who was from a dyeing and weaving family, and Juji ISHIMARU who was an art historian.
sen.cmt: ｆamily 小文字にしました。

sen.j: 朝鮮とのゆかり
sen.e: Connection with Korea
Connection with Korea
Connection with Korea

sen.j: 1919年3月1日に朝鮮半島で勃発した三・一独立運動に対する日本政府の弾圧に対し、「反抗する彼らよりも一層愚かなのは、圧迫する我々である。」と批判。
sen.e: He criticized the suppression movement of the Japanese government against March First Movement that occurred in Korean Peninsula on March 1, 1919 as 'the one that is more pitiful than them, who are revolting, are us, who are suppressing them.'

He criticized the suppression movement of the Japanese government against the March First Movement that occurred on the Korean Peninsula on March 1, 1919 as 'the ones who are more pitiful than them, who are revolting, are us, who are suppressing them.'

He criticized the suppression movement of the Japanese government against the March First Movement that occurred on the Korean Peninsula on March 1, 1919 as 'the ones who are more pitiful than them, who are revolting, are us, who are suppressing them.'

sen.j: 同時に、殆どの日本文化人が、朝鮮文化に興味を示さない中、朝鮮美術（とりわけ陶磁器など）に注目し、当時殆ど省みられることのなかった朝鮮の陶磁器や古美術をコレクションする。
sen.e: While most people that valued Japanese Culture did not show an interest in Korean culture, he focused on Korean Art (especially potteries) and made collection of Korean porcelains and antique arts not viewed by too many at that time.

While most people that valued Japanese Culture did not show an interest in Korean culture, he focused on Korean Art (especially potteries) and made a collection of Korean porcelains and antique arts not viewed by too many at that time.

While most people that valued Japanese Culture did not show an interest in Korean culture, he focused on Korean Art (especially potteries) and made a collection of Korean porcelains and antique arts not viewed by too many at that time.

sen.j: 1924年、京城府（現：ソウル特別市）に朝鮮民族美術館を設立。
sen.e: He established National Folk Museum of Korea in Keijo Prefecture (Present day Seoul Special City) in 1924.
He established the National Folk Museum of Korea in Keijo Prefecture (Present day Seoul Special City) in 1924.
He established the National Folk Museum of Korea in Keijo Prefecture (Present day Seoul Special City) in 1924.

sen.j: 朝鮮の文化にも深い理解を寄せ、京城において道路拡張のため李氏朝鮮時代の旧王宮である景福宮の光化門が取壊されそうになると、これに反対する評論「失はれんとする一朝鮮建築のために」を雑誌『改造 (雑誌)』に寄稿した。
sen.e: He had a great understanding of Korean culture and when Gwanghwamun of former imperial palace of Yi Dynasty Korea period was about to be destroyed due to widening of the road, he wrote a criticism 'do not lose it for the unified Korean establishment' in a magazine, "Kaizo" (Reconstruction).

He had a great understanding of Korean culture and when Gwanghwamun of the former imperial palace of the Yi Dynasty Korea period was about to be destroyed due to the widening of the road, he wrote a criticism 'do not lose it for the unified Korean establishment' in a magazine, "Kaizo" (Reconstruction).

He had a great understanding of Korean culture and when Gwanghwamun of the former imperial palace of the Yi Dynasty Korea period was about to be destroyed due to the widening of the road, he wrote a criticism 'do not lose it for the unified Korean establishment' in a magazine, "Kaizo" (Reconstruction).

sen.j: これが大きな反響を呼び、光化門は移築、保存された。
sen.e: This brought great response and Gwanghwamun was relocated and preserved.
This brought great response and Gwanghwamun was relocated and preserved.
This brought great response and Gwanghwamun was relocated and preserved.

sen.j: エピソード
sen.e: Episodes
Episodes
Episodes

sen.j: バーナード・リーチとの交友も知られる。
sen.e: He was known to have a friendly relation with Bernard LEACH.
He was known to have a friendly relation with Bernard LEACH.
He was known to have a friendly relation with Bernard LEACH.

sen.j: 『バーナード・リーチ日本絵日記』を訳している。
sen.e: He translated "Bernard LEACH, Picture Diary in Japan."
He translated "Bernard LEACH, Picture Diary in Japan."
He translated "Bernard LEACH, Picture Diary in Japan."

sen.j: 2002年に講談社学術文庫で再刊。
sen.e: It was republished by Academic paperback library, Kodansha Ltd. in 2002.
It was republished by the Academic paperback library, Kodansha Ltd. in 2002.
It was republished by the Academic paperback library, Kodansha Ltd. in 2002.

sen.j: またバーナード・リーチ・河井寛次郎・濱田庄司述、柳宗悦編『焼物の本』（水尾比呂志解説、共同通信社 1985年）が、日本民藝館創立50周年記念出版で出された。
sen.e: "Yakimono no hon" (A book of ceramics) (Commentary by Hiroshi MIZUO, Kyodo News, 1985) interpreted by Bernard LEACH, Kanjiro KAWAI, Shoji HAMADA, and edited by Muneyoshi YANAGI was published as the Fiftieth Anniversary since the establishment of The Japan Folk Crafts Museum.

"Yakimono no hon" (A book of ceramics) (Commentary by Hiroshi MIZUO, Kyodo News, 1985) interpreted by Bernard LEACH, Kanjiro KAWAI, Shoji HAMADA, and edited by Muneyoshi YANAGI was published for Fiftieth Anniversary of the establishment of The Japan Folk Crafts Museum.

"Yakimono no hon" (A book of ceramics) (Commentary by Hiroshi MIZUO, Kyodo News, 1985) interpreted by Bernard LEACH, Kanjiro KAWAI, Shoji HAMADA, and edited by Muneyoshi YANAGI was published for Fiftieth Anniversary of the establishment of The Japan Folk Crafts Museum.
sen.cmt: 全角の括弧を半角にしました。不要なスペースを削除しました。

sen.j: 江戸時代に全国各地を廻国し造仏活動を行い独特の「微笑仏」を残した木喰行道や妙好人の研究を行った。
sen.e: He studied Mokujiki Gyodo and myokonin (pious followers of the Jodo Shinshu sect), who travelled around Japan and built Buddhist statues and left unique 'Mishobutsu' (Smiling Buddha).
He studied Mokujiki Gyodo and myokonin (pious followers of the Jodo Shinshu sect), who travelled around Japan and built Buddhist statues and left unique 'Mishobutsu' (Smiling Buddha).
He studied Mokujiki Gyodo and myokonin (pious followers of the Jodo Shinshu sect), who travelled around Japan and built Buddhist statues and left unique 'Mishobutsu' (Smiling Buddha).

sen.j: 特に木喰研究は柳宗悦の木食仏発見が契機となったことで知られる。
sen.e: Especially the Mokujiki study was famous for taking the opportunity of the discovery of Mokujikibutsu of Muneyoshi YANAGI.
Especially the Mokujiki study was famous for taking the opportunity of the discovery of Mokujikibutsu of Muneyoshi YANAGI.
Especially the Mokujiki study was famous for taking the opportunity of the discovery of Mokujikibutsu of Muneyoshi YANAGI.

sen.j: 春秋社版「選集9巻」に『木食上人』
sen.e: "Mokujiki shonin" (wood eating holy Buddhist monk) was collected within "Selected works, Volume Nine" printed by Shunjusha Publishing Company.
"Mokujiki shonin" (wood eating holy Buddhist monk) was collected within "Selected works, Volume Nine" printed by Shunjusha Publishing Company.
"Mokujiki shonin" (wood eating holy Buddhist monk) was collected within "Selected works, Volume Nine" printed by Shunjusha Publishing Company.

sen.j: 仏教（禅）学者の鈴木大拙は学習院高等部時代の柳の英語教師。
sen.e: Daisetsu SUZUKI, who was the researcher for Buddhism (Zen), was the English teacher of Yanagi during his high school days.
Daisetsu SUZUKI, who was a researcher of Buddhism (Zen), was an English teacher for Yanagi during his high school days.
Daisetsu SUZUKI, who was a researcher of Buddhism (Zen), was an English teacher for Yanagi during his high school days.

sen.j: 追悼文「柳君を憶ふ」を遺している。
sen.e: He left a sentence posthumously, 'I think of Yanagi.'
He left the words, 'I think of Yanagi,' posthumously.
He left the words, 'I think of Yanagi,' posthumously.

sen.j: 筑摩書房版全集25巻は1980年から1992年までかかった。
sen.e: The complete twenty five volumes were published by Chikuma Shobo Publishers, and took from 1980 to 1992 to complete.
All twenty five volumes were published by Chikuma Shobo Publishers, and took from 1980 to 1992 to complete.
All 25 volumes were published by Chikuma Shobo Publishers, and took from 1980 to 1992 to complete.

sen.j: 20巻目までは毎月刊行されたが、21巻は書簡集上中下巻で1989年に、最終巻の22巻は上下巻で1992年に、各巻とも1万5千円前後で刊行された。
sen.e: Up to 20th volume was published monthly, but the 21st volume published in 1989 was a collection of letters divided into three sections, and the last 22nd volume published in 1992 was divided into two sections, and each was sold with the price of approximately 15,000 yen.

Up to the 20th volume were published monthly, but the 21st volume published in 1989 was a collection of letters divided into three sections, and the 22nd volume published in 1992 was divided into two sections, and each was sold for the price of approximately 15,000 yen.

Up to the 20th volume were published monthly, but the 21st volume published in 1989 was a collection of letters divided into three sections, and the 22nd volume published in 1992 was divided into two sections, and each was sold for the price of approximately 15,000 yen.

sen.j: 新たに発見された書簡の蒐集に加え、未発表の原稿作品の収録、資料や年譜の編集に10年以上費やした為である。
sen.e: He must have devoted more than a decade to compose letters, collecting unpublished manuscripts, and editing documents and chronological history.
He must have devoted more than a decade to compose letters, collecting unpublished manuscripts, and editing documents and chronological history.
He must have devoted more than a decade to compose letters, collecting unpublished manuscripts, and editing documents and chronological history.

sen.j: ゆえに全巻揃いの古書は高価である。
sen.e: As a result, the complete volume of the old document became expensive.
As a result, the complete volume of the old documents became expensive.
As a result, the complete volume of the old documents became expensive.

sen.j: 機関誌月刊民芸運動は、1939(昭和14)年4月号から1946(昭和21)年7月号まで、戦局悪化による休刊をはさんで刊行された。
sen.e: In-house monthly magazine Mingei Movement was published between April issue of 1939 to July issue of 1946 except for publications suspended due to worsening condition of war.
An in-house monthly magazine, Mingei Movement, was published between April 1939 to July 1946 except for publications suspended due to the worsening condition of war.
An in-house monthly magazine, Mingei Movement, was published between April 1939 to July 1946 except for publications suspended due to the worsening condition of war.

sen.j: 1955(昭和30)年に日本民芸協会で復刊している。
sen.e: It resumed publishing in Japan Folk Handicraft Association in 1955.
It resumed publishing in the Japan Folk Handicraft Association in 1955.
It resumed publishing in the Japan Folk Handicraft Association in 1955.

sen.j: 2008年に『復刻版 月刊民藝・民藝』が、不二出版で刊行。
sen.e: "Reprint of Monthly Mingei" was published by Fuji shuppan Publishers in 2008.
"Reprint of Monthly Mingei" was published by Fuji shuppan Publishers in 2008.
"Reprint of Monthly Mingei" was published by Fuji shuppan Publishers in 2008.

sen.j: 和装本による機関誌「工藝」は1931(昭和6)年から1943(昭和18)年にかけ114号までが、休刊をはさみ1946(昭和21)年から1951(昭和26)年まで120号を刊行した。
sen.e: Up to a Volume 114 of In-house magazine "Kogei" (Crafts) of a Japanese style books were published from 1931 to 1934, and was suspended temporarily before publishing up to Volume 120 from 1946 to 1951.

sen.j: 最終号は「大津絵」である。
sen.e: The last issue was 'Otsu-e' (Otsu paintings, named after the town of Otsu in Shiga Prefecture).
